Articles.Content:
That\'s right! All you need to do is summit your mission on this topic.* I pick the best mission every week and that person wins one of my rockets. It\'s that simple! ;D

*Limit one ship a week.

I\'ve tried to land an entire rocket on Minmus and then proceed to land the entire thing back on Kerbin, without a single decoupler or snapping bits off on terrain. The only thing stopping me is that I really have no idea when to burn for Minmus.
Get into a 100km orbit with the same inclination as Minmus (6 degrees, ish.) quicksave, then wait until you see Minmus rise over the horizon. Burn baby burn.

Get into a 100km orbit with the same inclination as Minmus (6 degrees, ish.) quicksave, then wait until you see Minmus rise over the horizon. Burn baby burn.

Huh. I\'ve heard that moonrise burn works with minmus, but I\'ve never actually been able to see it.

Maybe I\'m just looking in the wrong place.

I\'ve tried to land an entire rocket on Minmus and then proceed to land the entire thing back on Kerbin, without a single decoupler or snapping bits off on terrain. The only thing stopping me is that I really have no idea when to burn for Minmus.

Try this:

Yesterday i landed a rather large zoxygene supply base on the Mun.

It\'s a newly designed vessel and it was during one of the launch/ascent test flights that i decided to continue to the Mun, just for the heck of it.

That launch/ascent test did in fact turn up a major flaw, the fuel drains asymmetrical and i almost lost control of the ship, wasting quite a bit of fuel. I had to use the lander stage for the final part of transmunar injection. It landed safely with only a few drops of fuel left.

I\'ve tried to land an entire rocket on Minmus and then proceed to land the entire thing back on Kerbin, without a single decoupler or snapping bits off on terrain. The only thing stopping me is that I really have no idea when to burn for Minmus.

Well you could try what I do... burn straight away from Kerbin until you are close to Minmus\' orbital path and then just stay there and wait for it to swing around. Then burn towards it and get captured in its SoI; burn retrograde until you\'re in an orbit and then pick your landing site. Since Kerbin\'s gravitational pull is super weak at 46 megaklicks, this works for me most of the time.

It may be horrendously inefficient, but it\'s always different every time and there\'s always a chance to goof it up and fail, which makes it more exciting to me
